title: Exercises from Week 3, Lecture 1: Names and Values
text:
For these exercises, we will learn how to use the lobstr package to get information about objects in our environment.
Goal: By the end of these exercises, you will be able to determine whether an operation makes a copy, and compute the amount of memory each object occupies.
You will create a separate .qmd file and complete the following exercises that will then be committed and pushed in your SDS 270 repository.

title: Exercises from Week 3, Lecture 1: Names and Values
text:
For these exercises, we will learn how to use the lobstr package to get information about objects in our environment.
Goal: By the end of these exercises, you will be able to determine whether an operation makes a copy, and compute the amount of memory each object occupies.
You will create a separate .qmd file and complete the following exercises that will then be committed and pushed in your SDS 270 repository.

title: Exercises from Week 3, Lecture 1: Names and Values
text:
Exercises

Measuring Memory
First, load the lobstr package. This package contains many functions that will make it easier for us to figure out what R is doing under the hood. Also load the tidyverse package.

library(lobstr)

Warning: package 'lobstr' was built under R version 4.4.3

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'lubridate' was built under R version 4.4.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.6.0
✔ ggplot2   4.0.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.2.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Your workspace should be empty.






ImportantQ1:



Use ls() to list the objects in your workspace. If it is not empty, use the broom icon in the Environment tab in RStudio to empty it.


Before we do anything, how much memory is being used by our R session?

mem_used()

85.34 MB


Recall that a byte is eight bits. A byte is a very small amount of information, typically used to store one character. A kilobyte is 1000 bytes, and a megabyte is 1000 kilobytes, etc. You should familiarize yourself briefly with the orders of magnitude of data.
Now suppose we add some things to our workspace. We can add objects, functions, or load packages. Does loading a package increase the memory used by our session?






ImportantQ2:



Use the library() command to load the broom package. Then check the memory usage with mem_used(). Does loading a package increase the amount of memory used? By how much?








ImportantQ3:



What about loading a data set? Use the data() command to load the iris data set. Does that increase the memory usage? By how much?








ImportantQ4:



Use obj_size() to measure the amount of memory that iris takes up. Was the increase you observed previously equal to this amount?




Making Copies
As much fun as it is to make copies, each copy occupies memory. Generally, we want to minimize the amount of memory that our code needs to run.
Let’s store the amount of memory we are currently using.

before <- mem_used()

Note the memory location of the iris data frame.

ref(iris)

█ [1:0x212ac05e468] <df[,5]> 
├─Sepal.Length = [2:0x212a27ea260] <dbl> 
├─Sepal.Width = [3:0x212a27e9360] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Length = [4:0x212a27ea760] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Width = [5:0x212a27e8460] <dbl> 
└─Species = [6:0x212a08da7f0] <fct> 


Note that we can bind a second name my_iris to the iris data frame, without making a copy.

my_iris <- iris
ref(my_iris)

█ [1:0x212ac05e468] <df[,5]> 
├─Sepal.Length = [2:0x212a27ea260] <dbl> 
├─Sepal.Width = [3:0x212a27e9360] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Length = [4:0x212a27ea760] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Width = [5:0x212a27e8460] <dbl> 
└─Species = [6:0x212a08da7f0] <fct> 


Now let’s change the data frame in a way that forces a copy to be made.

my_iris <- my_iris |>
  mutate(sepal_area = Sepal.Length * Sepal.Width)
ref(my_iris)

█ [1:0x212a94adc68] <df[,6]> 
├─Sepal.Length = [2:0x212a27ea260] <dbl> 
├─Sepal.Width = [3:0x212a27e9360] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Length = [4:0x212a27ea760] <dbl> 
├─Petal.Width = [5:0x212a27e8460] <dbl> 
├─Species = [6:0x212a08da7f0] <fct> 
└─sepal_area = [7:0x212a27ecf60] <dbl> 


Note that the memory locations of my_iris and iris are not the same anymore. However, the memory locations of the underlying vectors are the same!






ImportantQ5:



Use before and mem_used() to calculate how much extra memory the copy of my_iris occupies.








ImportantQ6:



Is the difference you observed above equal to the size of the new column we created? Why or why not?


Different representations of the same data may have different memory footprints. Suppose we change the iris data set into its long format.

iris_long <- iris |>
  pivot_longer(-Species, names_to = "type", values_to = "measurement")







ImportantQ7:



Does iris_long take up the same amount of memory as iris? Why or why not?


We know that tibbles are like data.frames. Do they take up the same amount of memory?

before <- mem_used()
iris_tbl <- iris_long |>
  as_tibble()
mem_used() - before

-6.07 kB

class(iris_tbl)

[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"


Does converting a data.frame to a tbl force a copy?

ref(iris_tbl)

█ [1:0x212a6144918] <tibble[,3]> 
├─Species = [2:0x212a00ed450] <fct> 
├─type = [3:0x212a01ddf50] <chr> 
└─measurement = [4:0x212a01d4750] <dbl> 

ref(iris_long)

█ [1:0x212a925c968] <tibble[,3]> 
├─Species = [2:0x212a00ed450] <fct> 
├─type = [3:0x212a01ddf50] <chr> 
└─measurement = [4:0x212a01d4750] <dbl> 








ImportantQ8:



Discuss how using a tibble changes the memory footprint relative to using a data.frame.




Tracing memory
Unfortunately, due to various complications and optimizations, it’s not always possible to reason ahead of time about whether R will make a copy of an object. Instead, we can use the tracemem() function to have R tell us whether it makes a copy and why.
First, note the memory location of iris.

tracemem(iris)

[1] "<00000212AC05E468>"


We are now tracing this memory location. Some types of computations we make on iris do not require making a copy.

iris |>
  pull(Petal.Length) |>
  mean()

[1] 3.758


However, if we modify iris using mutate(), a copy does get made.

iris |>
  mutate(petal_area = Petal.Length * Petal.Width) |>
  as_tibble()

tracemem[0x00000212ac05e468 -> 0x000002129fcbf808]: initialize <Anonymous> mutate_cols mutate.data.frame mutate as_tibble eval eval withVisible withCallingHandlers eval eval with_handlers doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList doWithOneRestart withOneRestart withRestartList withRestarts <Anonymous> evaluate in_dir in_input_dir eng_r block_exec call_block process_group withCallingHandlers with_options <Anonymous> process_file <Anonymous> <Anonymous> execute .main

ImportantQ9:



Experiment with different operations after invoking tracemem(). Can you get a feel for what operations induce copies?

title: Control Flow
text:
Today

Control flow

Choices
Loops


We will focus on primarily Chapter 5 from Advanced R.

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
Control Flow

Can be seen in the following ways:

Choices

if/else and switch statements
Includes debugging actions (e.g. errors, tryCatch)

Loops

for/while loops


Allows us to get through one process

title: Control Flow
section: Why would we use control flow?
text:
Why would we use control flow?

Different processes/outcomes for certain actions

e.g. process control: stop machine if variance is high
e.g. certain event on map: place unique symbol there

Repetition across sequence

e.g. multiply 3 to each element in array

Automation

e.g. simulations

title: Control Flow
text:
Situation

Suppose we play one half-inning of a baseball game. Keep in mind, we have the following:

3 outs to end the half-inning
For each play, it results in a single, HR, or out (simple example)



We will use this as our motivating example for our understanding of choices and loops.

title: Control Flow
text:
Choices

In R: can be seen as if/else structure, ifelse() function, or switch() function

Completes task based on condition
e.g. do this if single is hit, do this otherwise

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
ifelse()

Suppose I want to work with multiple logical values (i.e. element-wise comparison)

Use ifelse() statement

First argument: conditional
Second argument: result if element-wise condition is true
Third argument: result if element-wise condition is false




nums <- c(2, 5, 3, 8, 1)
ifelse(nums %% 2 == 0, nums, 0)

[1] 2 0 0 8 0

title: Control Flow
text:
Example: if/else statement

runs <- c(0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 4, 0, 0, 0)
scored <- ifelse(runs > 0, T, F)
scored

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE

title: Control Flow
text:
Activity: if/else statement

runs <- c(0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 4, 0, 0, 0)
scored <- ifelse(runs > 0, T, F)
scored

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE


Question 3: Suppose if we have less than 0 runs, I want to output an NA. How can I change the ifelse() statement above to do this?

title: Control Flow
text:
Alternative: case_when()

From dplyr package


library(dplyr)
case_when(runs > 0 ~ "True", 
          runs == 0 ~ "False", 
          runs < 0 ~ "Runs are invalid.")

[1] "False" "True"  "False" "False" "False" "True"  "False" "False" "False"

title: Control Flow
text:
switch()

Used on a character to perform certain action


stat = "mean"
switch(stat, 
       mean = mean(nums),
       median = median(nums), 
       sd = sd(nums), 
       stop("Invalid stat request."))

[1] 3.8

title: Control Flow
text:
Activity: switch()
Question 4: Write a switch() function that takes a single character and does the following:

Print 1 for “single”
Print 4 for “home run”
Stop otherwise

title: Control Flow
text:
Loops

Iterating over items in a vector

item in array
object in sequence (e.g. i in 1:10)

Actions happen within loop


for (i in 1:10){
  print(i)
}

[1] 1
[1] 2
[1] 3
[1] 4
[1] 5
[1] 6
[1] 7
[1] 8
[1] 9
[1] 10

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
For-loop notes

Pre-allocating the output container is recommended

Replacement is more efficient than adding to the output container
e.g. vector("list", length(x)), rep(-1, length(x))

Be careful about the vector you iterate over

: can iterate 1 up or 1 down
Specify which vector to iterate through

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
While loops and repeats

Two specific types of for loops:

while loops: repeat until condition is not satisfied
repeat: repeat forever until break occurs

title: Control Flow
text:
Example: while loop

xVal = 6
while(xVal < 10){
  print(xVal)
  xVal <- xVal + 1
}

[1] 6
[1] 7
[1] 8
[1] 9

title: Control Flow
Control Flow
text:
The argument against for loops

R succeeds when using vectorized operations

e.g. colSums(), adding two vectors together
A for-loop does so element by element, making things slow

If possible:

Use an apply() function
Use the map() function

title: Control Flow
text:
apply() function

Functional operation, usually done on a list (or data frame)
apply(x, margin, function)

x is an array
margin specifies direction function will be applied over

1 for function completed on each row, 2 on each column

function is the function being applied to object

title: Control Flow
text:
map() function

# For loop
y <- list()
for (i in seq_along(x)) {
  y[[i]] <- my_fun(i) 
}

# Map
y <- map(x, my_fun)

title: Control Flow
text:
Example: matrix

myMat <- matrix(rnorm(100, 0, 1), nrow = 5, ncol = 20)


timerFor <- Sys.time()
columnSums <- rep(-1, ncol(myMat))
for (i in 1:ncol(myMat)){
  columnSums[i] <- sum(myMat[, i])
}
Sys.time() - timerFor

Time difference of 0.004012108 secs
